displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see if she’s out here to sort of get a sense that I can give you some feedback that it will be in the next day or the next week to sort of say to you - Patient: And then you will let us know about chemo Doctor: Yeah, we’ve got a little bit of a window, so we probably have until early February to get started. Patient: Oh so it won’t get started before that? Doctor: No, it could start as soon as you participate in the study, we can do that, but it’s not urgent that it has to be done before Christmas or before the new year’s or before Martin Luther King - Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Okay? Okay, let me see if she’s around so I can just give you a time frame um and uh thanks for bringing this in. This is very helpful. Patient: Good. Um hum. Family Member: We were happy when the results came in. Doctor: Yeah, no genes . Okay, great, good to see you. Family Member: Okay, thanks.

Patient: …when we make the decision, we’re going to have to weigh it on what what you’re telling us. Uh so you kind of know where I’m coming from. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Um what is where you’re coming from at this point? What is it that you would suggest? What would - Doctor: I think there are like two broad ways to tackle this. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And at this point in time they are mutually exclusive. And in the future the two are probably going to be combined, but right now they are mutually exclusive. One is to give a radio therapy in the absence of hormone therapy. In other words try give you a non-hormonal treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Such as radiation instead of hormone therapy in order to delay you know the need for hormone therapy. And the other is to start the hormone therapy now and try to combine it with something that may make the hormone therapy work better and longer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: From what I’m hearing and reading between the lines, what I think I’m hearing is that you’d rather try at this point in time something that is a non-hormonal approach such as radiotherapy. And if that is the case, I think that we have an interesting study that I could talk to you about which is using what we call stereotactic radiotherapy. It’s also called CyberKnife because the company that makes the machine that delivers the radiation is called CyberKnife. It’s not a knife; it’s a misnomer. It’s not surgery – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But because the beam of radiation is so precise, it’s called a knife because it’s as precise as a surgeon’s knife. Um if you think that I’m misunderstanding and you really are more open to the hormone therapy option as well or instead of radiation and we also have a trial in that category which is trying to ask the question about whether all hormone therapy in conjunction with a new hormone therapy is better than just the old hormone therapy by itself, the conventional.

Patient: As long as I’m feeling up to it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. Doctor: You’ve got to take care of business. Go ahead. You know we’ll be here a while. (Laughs) Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh Doctor: But I think the way back when CAT scan you had some. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay but they were very small and they may not be something at all significant. So you know I think your last CAT scan again barely showed anything Patient: Right. Doctor: so I don’t think we need to worry about those. But doing that Xofigo treatment would absolutely be another valid option if you don’t want to do chemotherapy. So the good news is that you have some options for standard treatment and you have some options for clinical trials. So you know either way we have options. I’m just reluctant to switch things if the scans don’t show us any change. Family Member 2: Right, right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: Alright. Appreciate it. Doctor: Safe travels. Patient: Same to you. Doctor: Are you going back to F___? Patient: We are, later today. Doctor: Snow in N__, really crazy? Patient: It was cold. It was in the, in the thirties that night, but it’s back up in the seventies now. Doctor: Well you’re also in N__t so you’re used to that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Do you, you have my phone information? Patient: I don’t think I have your e-mail. Doctor: Do you want it? Do you want a phone? I could use yours too. Okay? Uh, here’s my card. So my office is here. Well your phone number is in here. Just give it to me on the back of the card.

Family Member: You know you said Provenge is off the table but he keeps asking why. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: I forgot about that, yeah. Family Member: Because the doctor said. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, no. When your PSA kind of creeps up a bit too high and you’re not as controlled and your symptomatic that’s not the group that benefits the most. There’s a kind of small amount of cancer, small amount of PSA, kind of like less than 22 would be ideal. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. But you could get there again once like so he said can I get Provenge after Xofigo. Sure, if your pain was controlled. Even if your PSA wasn’t so low, having discomfort puts you in a different group. It just means your cancer is not behaving and having it go up on treatment is different than you not on anything and having it go up Patient: Okay. Doctor: and at this moment it’s not behaving. Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we…

Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, we can’t, you know. That part’s okay. Let me see this other skinny leg. Patient: Yeah, you’re right they’re skinny. Doctor: There’s no change there so that’s good but you think up here is swollen? Patient: Well, no, I don’t think it’s swollen. It’s just like a… Doctor: A little pain? Patient: Well, the muscle. Doctor: Yeah. Hang on. That’s not swollen. Okay, we got a plan. Patient: Like, huh. Doctor: We got a plan. Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night.

Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles) Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense? Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so. Doctor: You could probably talk the medical lingo pretty easily now. Patient: Yeah, right. (Slight laughter) Healthcare Professional: Yes. Patient: I saw a news lady on TV --- Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: -- And I thought of, I thought of T____.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

Patient: Are we giving you a couple alternatives? Doctor: Yeah give me a couple options. Patient: Thursday this week and uh… Family Member: Monday? Patient: No No Tuesday next week. Doctor: Tuesday, good. That works out because then Tuesday I’ll be there too if you have any questions about the consent if anything comes up. So we’ll try for this week Thursday or Tuesday next week. Patient: Yeah. Thursday afternoon. Doctor: Afternoon, sorry. Got it. Family Member: So let’s – okay so that happens. Then what happens next? Doctor: So at that point if everything is looking good we will also be scheduling the biopsy and then the treatment date after that. Patient: And when do I start on the BET? Doctor: So the…

Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body.
